questiontext.text:
Verify Gauss’ theorem for the vector field \(\underline{F} = {@aa@}xz\underline{i} - y^2\underline{j} + yz\underline{k}\) and the cuboid \(0 \leq x \leq {@bb@}\), \(0 \leq y \leq {@cc@}\), \(0 \leq z \leq {@dd@}\).

  1. First find \(\underline{\nabla} \cdot \underline{F}\)

    \(\underline{\nabla} \cdot \underline{F} =\) [[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]] [[feedback:prt1]]

  2. Evaluate the integral \(\displaystyle \int^{z={@dd@}}_{z=0} \int^{y={@cc@}}_{y=0} \int^{x={@bb@}}_{x=0} \underline{\nabla} \cdot \underline{F}\ \mathrm{d}x\ \mathrm{d}y\ \mathrm{d}z\)

    \(\displaystyle \int^{z={@dd@}}_{z=0} \int^{y={@cc@}}_{y=0} \int^{x={@bb@}}_{x=0} \underline{\nabla} \cdot \underline{F}\ \mathrm{d}x\ \mathrm{d}y\ \mathrm{d}z = \) [[input:ans2]] [[validation:ans2]] [[feedback:prt2]]

  3. For each side, evaluate the normal vector \(\underline{\mathrm{d}S}\) and the surface integral \(\displaystyle \iint_S \underline{F} \cdot \underline{\mathrm{d}S}\).

    For \(x=0\): \(\underline{\mathrm{d}s} = \mathrm{d}\)[[input:ans3]] \(\mathrm{d}\)[[input:ans4]] \((\)[[input:ans5]] \(\underline{i} +\)[[input:ans6]] \(\underline{j} +\)[[input:ans7]] \(\underline{k})\) and \(\displaystyle \iint_S \underline{F} \cdot \underline{\mathrm{d}S} =\)[[input:ans8]] [[validation:ans3]][[validation:ans4]][[validation:ans5]][[validation:ans6]][[validation:ans7]][[validation:ans8]] [[feedback:prt3]]

    For \(x={@bb@}\): \(\underline{\mathrm{d}s} = \mathrm{d}\)[[input:ans9]] \(\mathrm{d}\)[[input:ans10]] \((\)[[input:ans11]] \(\underline{i} +\)[[input:ans12]] \(\underline{j} +\)[[input:ans13]] \(\underline{k})\) and \(\displaystyle \iint_S \underline{F} \cdot \underline{\mathrm{d}S} =\)[[input:ans14]][[validation:ans9]][[validation:ans10]][[validation:ans11]] [[validation:ans12]][[validation:ans13]][[validation:ans14]][[feedback:prt4]]

    For \(y=0\): \(\underline{\mathrm{d}s} = \mathrm{d}\)[[input:ans15]] \(\mathrm{d}\)[[input:ans16]] \((\)[[input:ans17]] \(\underline{i} +\)[[input:ans18]] \(\underline{j} +\)[[input:ans19]] \(\underline{k})\) and \(\displaystyle \iint_S \underline{F} \cdot \underline{\mathrm{d}S} =\)[[input:ans20]] [[validation:ans15]][[validation:ans16]][[validation:ans17]][[validation:ans18]][[validation:ans19]][[validation:ans20]] [[feedback:prt5]]

    For \(y={@cc@}\): \(\underline{\mathrm{d}s} = \mathrm{d}\)[[input:ans21]] \(\mathrm{d}\)[[input:ans22]] \((\)[[input:ans23]] \(\underline{i} +\)[[input:ans24]]\(\underline{j} +\)[[input:ans25]] \(\underline{k})\) and \(\displaystyle \iint_S \underline{F} \cdot \underline{\mathrm{d}S} =\)[[input:ans26]] [[validation:ans21]] [[validation:ans22]][[validation:ans23]][[validation:ans24]][[validation:ans25]][[validation:ans26]] [[feedback:prt6]]

    For \(z=0\): \(\underline{\mathrm{d}s} = \mathrm{d}\)[[input:ans27]] \(\mathrm{d}\)[[input:ans28]] \((\)[[input:ans29]] \(\underline{i} +\)[[input:ans30]] \(\underline{j} +\)[[input:ans31]] \(\underline{k})\) and \(\displaystyle \iint_S \underline{F} \cdot \underline{\mathrm{d}S} =\)[[input:ans32]] [[validation:ans27]][[validation:ans28]][[validation:ans29]][[validation:ans30]][[validation:ans31]][[validation:ans32]][[feedback:prt7]]

    For \(z={@dd@}\): \(\underline{\mathrm{d}s} = \mathrm{d}\)[[input:ans33]] \(\mathrm{d}\)[[input:ans34]] \((\)[[input:ans35]] \(\underline{i} +\)[[input:ans36]] \(\underline{j} +\)[[input:ans37]] \(\underline{k})\) and \(\displaystyle \iint_S \underline{F} \cdot \underline{\mathrm{d}S} =\)[[input:ans38]] [[validation:ans33]][[validation:ans34]][[validation:ans35]][[validation:ans36]][[validation:ans37]][[validation:ans38]] [[feedback:prt8]]

    4. Note the sum of the line integrals in (c) and compare it to your answer in (b).

generalfeedback.text:
We aim to verify Gauss’ theorem for the vector field \(\underline{F} = {@aa@}xz\underline{i} - y^2\underline{j} + yz\underline{k}\) and the cuboid \(0 \leq x \leq {@bb@}\), \(0 \leq y \leq {@cc@}\), \(0 \leq z \leq {@dd@}\).

(a) \(\underline{\nabla} \cdot \underline{F} = \dfrac{\partial}{\partial x}({@aa@}xz) + \dfrac{\partial}{\partial y}(- y^2) + \dfrac{\partial}{\partial z}(yz) = {@aa*z@} - 2y + y = {@aa*z - y@}\)

(b) \[ \begin{aligned} \int^{z={@dd@}}_{z=0} \int^{y={@cc@}}_{y=0} \int^{x={@bb@}}_{x=0} \underline{\nabla} \cdot \underline{F}\ \mathrm{d}x\ \mathrm{d}y\ \mathrm{d}z &= \int^{z={@dd@}}_{z=0} \int^{y={@cc@}}_{y=0} \int^{x={@bb@}}_{x=0} {@ta1@}\ \mathrm{d}x\ \mathrm{d}y\ \mathrm{d}z\\ &= \int^{z={@dd@}}_{z=0} \int^{y={@cc@}}_{y=0}\left[{@two_int_first_indef@}\right]^{x={@bb@}}_{x=0}\ \mathrm{d}y\ \mathrm{d}z\\ &= \int^{z={@dd@}}_{z=0} \int^{y={@cc@}}_{y=0} {@two_int_first_def@}\ \mathrm{d}y\ \mathrm{d}z\\ &=\int^{z={@dd@}}_{z=0} \left[{@two_int_second_indef@}\right]^{y={@cc@}}_{y=0}\ \mathrm{d}z\\ &=\int^{z={@dd@}}_{z=0} {@two_int_second_def@}\ \mathrm{d}z\\ &= \left[{@two_int_third_indef@}\right]^{z={@dd@}}_{z=0}\\ &= {@ta2@} \end{aligned} \]

(c) We aim to calculate the surface integral \(\displaystyle \iint_S \underline{F} \cdot \underline{\mathrm{d}S}\) across all sides of the cuboid:

For \(x=0\) we know that \(\underline{\mathrm{d}S} = -\underline{i}\mathrm{d}y\mathrm{d}z\) due to it lying in the Oyz plane. We can then calculate the surface integral as follows: \[ \begin{aligned} \iint_S \underline{F} \cdot \underline{\mathrm{d}S} = -\int^{z={@dd@}}_{z=0} \int^{y={@cc@}}_{y=0} {@aa@}xz \mathrm{d}y\mathrm{d}z = 0 \end{aligned} \] As \(x=0\) at all points.

For \(x={@bb@}\) we know that \(\underline{\mathrm{d}S} = \underline{i}\mathrm{d}y\mathrm{d}z\) due to it lying in the Oyz plane. We can then calculate the surface integral as follows: \[ \begin{aligned} \iint_S \underline{F} \cdot \underline{\mathrm{d}S} &= \int^{z={@dd@}}_{z=0} \int^{y={@cc@}}_{y=0} {@aa@}xz \mathrm{d}y\mathrm{d}z\\ &= \int^{z={@dd@}}_{z=0} \int^{y={@cc@}}_{y=0} {@aa*bb*z@}\ \mathrm{d}y\ \mathrm{d}z\\ &= \int^{z={@dd@}}_{z=0} {@cc*aa*bb*z@}\ \mathrm{d}z\\ &= \left[{@cc*aa*bb*(z^2)/2@}\right]^{z={@dd@}}_{z=0}\\ &= {@cc*aa*bb*(dd^2)/2@}. \end{aligned} \]

For \(y=0\) we know that \(\underline{\mathrm{d}S} = -\underline{j}\mathrm{d}x\mathrm{d}z\) due to it lying in the Oxz plane. We can then calculate the surface integral as follows: \[ \begin{aligned} \iint_S \underline{F} \cdot \underline{\mathrm{d}S} &= -\int^{z={@dd@}}_{z=0} \int^{x={@bb@}}_{x=0} -y^2 \mathrm{d}x\mathrm{d}z\\ &= \int^{z={@dd@}}_{z=0} \int^{x={@bb@}}_{x=0} 0\ \mathrm{d}y\ \mathrm{d}z\\ &= 0 \end{aligned} \]

.

For \(y={@cc@}\) we know that \(\underline{\mathrm{d}S} = \underline{j}\mathrm{d}x\mathrm{d}z\) due to it lying in the Oxz plane. We can then calculate the surface integral as follows: \[ \begin{aligned} \iint_S \underline{F} \cdot \underline{\mathrm{d}S} &= \int^{z={@dd@}}_{z=0} \int^{x={@bb@}}_{x=0} -y^2 \mathrm{d}x\mathrm{d}z\\ &= -\int^{z={@dd@}}_{z=0} \int^{x={@bb@}}_{x=0} {@cc^2@}\ \mathrm{d}y\ \mathrm{d}z\\ &= -\int^{z={@dd@}}_{z=0} {@bb*cc^2@}\ \mathrm{d}z\\ &= {@-dd*bb*cc^2@}. \end{aligned} \]

For \(z=0\) we know that \(\underline{\mathrm{d}S} = -\underline{k}\mathrm{d}x\mathrm{d}y\) due to it lying in the Oxy plane. We can then calculate the surface integral as follows: \[ \begin{aligned} \iint_S \underline{F} \cdot \underline{\mathrm{d}S} &= \int^{y={@cc@}}_{y=0} \int^{x={@bb@}}_{x=0} yz \mathrm{d}x\mathrm{d}y\\ &= \int^{z={@dd@}}_{z=0} \int^{x={@bb@}}_{x=0} 0\ \mathrm{d}y\ \mathrm{d}y\\ &= 0. \end{aligned} \]

Finally for \(z={@dd@}\) we know that \(\underline{\mathrm{d}S} = \underline{k}\mathrm{d}x\mathrm{d}y\) due to it lying in the Oxy plane. We can then calculate the surface integral as follows: \[ \begin{aligned} \iint_S \underline{F} \cdot \underline{\mathrm{d}S} &= \int^{y={@cc@}}_{y=0} \int^{x={@bb@}}_{x=0} yz \mathrm{d}x\mathrm{d}y\\ &= \int^{y={@cc@}}_{y=0} \int^{x={@bb@}}_{x=0} {@y*dd@}\ \mathrm{d}y\ \mathrm{d}y\\ &= \int^{y={@cc@}}_{y=0} {@bb*y*dd@}\ \mathrm{d}y\\ &= \left[{@bb*(y^2)/2*dd@}\right]^{y={@cc@}}_{y=0}\\ &= {@bb*(cc^2)/2*dd@}. \end{aligned} \]

.

So we find that the surface integral overall is \(\displaystyle \iint_S \underline{F} \cdot \underline{\mathrm{d}S} = 0 + {@cc*aa*bb*(dd^2)/2@}+ 0 - {@dd*bb*cc^2@} + 0 + {@bb*(cc^2)/2*dd@} = {@cc*aa*bb*(dd^2)/2 - dd*bb*cc^2 + bb*(cc^2)/2*dd@}.\) This is the same as we found in (b), thus verifying Gauss' theorem.

prtcorrect.text: Correct answer, well done.

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Your answer is partially correct.

prtincorrect.text: Incorrect answer.

qtest.description: Test case assuming the teacher's input gets full marks.
